Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I glance at the clock on my telemarketing dashboard—my break is scheduled in ten minutes, but I’m already feeling the pressure. The automated compliance system is ruthless; even a minute of unscheduled downtime could mean a warning or worse. My headset buzzes with another call, but my phone vibrates with a reminder: today’s the last day to drop off my mail-in ballot. I rush to the polling station during my lunch, hoping to make it back in time. As I hand over my ballot, the poll worker frowns and points out a smudge on the envelope. “You’ll need to re-sign this, or your vote might not count,” she says, sliding a new envelope toward me. I glance at my watch—if I take even a few extra minutes, the system will flag me. But if I rush, my vote could be rejected. My job demands strict adherence to the schedule, but my duty as a voter means following every instruction. My heart pounds as I stand there, pen in hand, torn between the risk of disciplinary action and the fear of my voice not being heard.
